poem:
Julie's Revival

The morning light on 
Portland Road; plump 
cushions, whispered tales 
in Holland Park's embrace. 
Dishes left unsaid, shadows 
dance upon the walls. 
Time bends; a space 
where flavorless whispers 
flourish. Elegance in silence, 
Julie's breathes again.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Julie’s, London: ‘Its time has clearly come again’ – restaurant review Julie’s, 135 Portland Road, London W11 4LW (020 7229 8331). Starters £6-£19, mains £12-£40, desserts £8-£10, wines from £30 It’s very tempting to discuss Julie’s in London’s Holland Park without ever mentioning the food. That would be a thing, wouldn’t it: a restaurant review that went big on the plump furnishings and the clientele, but didn’t mention a single dish? If ever there was". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
